question: What impact have the delays in approval had on the Mechanical Completion requirements for the Oman LNG Power Plant Project?
ground_truth: The delays in approval have prevented the CONTRACTOR from fulfilling the requirements for the Mechanical Completion as provisioned under Clause 39 of the General Conditions of the Contract Section B-1, and therefore, the CONTRACTOR is prevented from issuing a notification to COMPANY for the signing of the Mechanical Completion Certificate under Clause 39.1.

M/s Oman LNG LLC,

EPC Services for Oman LNG Power Plant Project Muscat,

Sultanate of Oman.

Kind Attn: Mr. Mark McCarthy, Project Director, PMC

Contract Title: EPC Services for Oman LNG Power Plant Project Contract Number: QMP-17-876

Subject: Notice of Contractor's Claims pursuant to Clause 31.biz, Section B1, General Conditions of Contract- Delays to Milestone MS-G-04 [Achieve Mechanical Completion (1-6)]

Dear Sir,

ZPTE Powertech Engineering LLC is hereinafter referred to as “CONTRACTOR” and M/s Oman LNG LLC hereinafter referred to as "COMPANY".

We hereby submit our “Notice of Contractor's Claims" as under:

ne This ‘Claim Notice’ is being sent under Clause 31.biz, Section B1, General Conditions of Contract.

2. CONTRACTOR is executing MCC activities for various subsystems in order to achieve the requirements stipulated under MS-G-04, CONTRACTOR noted that there are gross delays in obtaining approval for MCCs from COMPANY which js illustrated under Annexure-A of this letter. It can be seen that delays in approval for some subsystems are in excess of 90 days.

3 Further, it is to be noted that CONTRACTOR for the Pre-commissioning activities completion allowed 251 days in the Baseline Programme. However, it is currently over 400 days and delays in obtaining approvals from COMPANY have not ceased.

4. On 20! January 2022, CONTRACTOR issued a list of 11 nos. MCC dossier (refer to Annexure-B) for which COMPANY was requested to expedite approval, however, there was no noticeable progress achieved in approval from COMPANY.

5s Based on the events described above, the requirements for the Mechanical Completion are not fulfilled as provisioned under Clause 39 of the General Conditions of the Contract Section B-1 and therefore, CONTRACTOR is prevented from issuing a notification to COMPANY for the signing of the Mechanical Completion Certificate under Clause 39.1.

question: What concerns does the contractor have regarding grid connection readiness for the Oman LNG Power Plant Project?
ground_truth: The contractor has concerns regarding the lack of clear direction from the company to support the contractor on the way forward for grid connection readiness. This has resulted in meetings going in circles without effective decisions, and the schedule is being driven by the GEG connection with the grid, which is on the critical path. The contractor is unable to proceed ahead on the subject due to this lack of direction.
contexts:
ZPTE/OLNG/LTR-503

Date: 09 October 2022

To, M/s Oman LNG LLC, EPC Services for Oman LNG Power Plant Project Muscat, Sultanate of Oman

Kind Attn: Mr. Carl Aldous, PMC

Contract Title: EPC Services for Oman LNG Power Plant Project Contract Number: QMP-17-876

Subject: Grid Connection Readiness

Dear Sir,

Contractor wish to record their concern against company direction on providing Grid to connect one GEG as requested by GEG Supplier. This topic is being discussed across the parties (MAN/ZPTE/PMC/OLNG) in the meeting for extensive durations and updated Actions points were circulated by MAN / Contractor on meeting days through e-mail respectively.

Due to non-availability of the clear direction from company side to support contractor on the way forward, contractor unable to proceed ahead on the subject and Meeting were going in circles without being effective as we don’t arrive at any decisions. In this regard, Contractor position on the connection with grid is listed below for the company information and we request company immediate action for the closeout without further delay, as schedule is being driven now by GEG Connection with the grid and it is on the critical path. The below position is already shared with company through e-mail dated 08th Oct 22 and same is again enclosed here.

1. Load shedding system Stage-1 Modification implementation: As requested by Company, the meeting with LSS Vendor-ABB has been organized on 10.10.2022, although it is not required as required documents are already approved and in Place for the implementation. “Contractor await for OLNG/PMC clearance to re- confirm vendor mobilization date and site implementation”.

2. 6 GTG + 1 GEG connection: Contractor furnished all necessary documents for short circuit related query. The functionality of IS Limiter will be same when operating 6 GTG + 0 GEG (As per OLNG present operating condition) and 6 GTG + 1 GEG. As advised by Company, we have again requested MOTT consent in this regard,

although the documents are already approved and implementation. (Note: Contractor will not be responsible for the delay in response by MOTT and if any commercial claim by MOTT for the response to the company request of functionality study to be supported/compensated by company)

in place

for the

3. BP-PMS operation when GEG grid connection: Company requirement is already briefed in the document 6A05-PP-ZPTE-002; SL. NO: 21, In this regard, we request company to close this item to proceed further process.

The above information confirms that the actions from contractor are closed and company to close the open actions which will enable to us to connect the engine with Grid on time as per forecast schedule and avoid any slippages in schedule. Contractor forecasted the Connection of engine with grid by 23rd Oct 22 and any further delays to be borne by company which includes Vendor Mobilization call , all necessary required permits.

Contractor reserve their rights to claim the loss of time and cost as per provision of contract.

For Zawawi Powertech Engineering LLC

Krishnaraj Bonagiri Project Director

question: What issues did the contractor face regarding the approval of permits in the Oman LNG Power Plant Project?
ground_truth: The contractor faced delays in the approval of permits, which were not addressed by the company. The MST for the Modification & Pre-Commissioning of 33 KV GIS Panel was approved on 19th Sep 22, and the permit was applied for the next day. However, the company only reverted with comments on 18th Oct 22, 30 days after the permit application, causing delays attributable to the company. Additionally, the permit for excavation was approved on 26th Sep 22, but clearance from the company was received only by 9th Oct 22, and the contractor is still waiting for clearance for the relaying of cables.
contexts:
ZPTE/OLNG/LTR-531

Date: 20-December-2022

To, M/s Oman LNG LLC, EPC Services for Oman LNG Power Plant Project Muscat, Sultanate of Oman.

Kind Attn: Mr. Carl Aldous, Project Director, PMC

Contract Title: EPC Services for Oman LNG Power Plant Project Contract Number: QMP-17-876

Reference

: Contractor Letter ZPTE/OLNG/LTR-505 dated 11th Oct 22 Company Letter 6A05/OLNG/ZPTE/LTR/0461 dated 14th Dec 22

Subject: Delay in Progress of Connection of New HV cable circuit between SS01 new GIS SB1B1-'R6' Feeder to new SS15 GIS SB15B1-'L6' Feeder- Contractor Response

Dear Sir,

We acknowledge the receipt of the company letter and contractor response is as follows

Company to note that contractor claim is against delay in approval of permits, which company has not addressed in its letter and rather commented on contractors planning, which is neither in conjunction with the context of the letter, nor addresses the issue.

The MST (6A05-EL-CWP-0617- Rev B) for the Modification & Pre-Commissioning of 33 KV GIS Panel SB1B1-R6 Feeder at SS-01 approved only on 19th Sep 22 and Permit applied immediately on next day. Company reverted with its comments only on 18th Oct 22 that is after 30 days from permit application. This is clear evidence that the delays are attributable to the company. Further, inline to the company comments, contractor have shared the supporting documents on 24th Oct 22 and Permit is still open with company till date, adding on to the delays.

Company comments against contractor request of Clearance for the HV cable rerouting is not valid. Although the permit approved on 26th Sep 22 for excavation, clearance from company received only by 9th Oct 22 and excavation completed on 10th Nov 22. With regards to the relaying of cables, contractor is still waiting for clearance and following up on weekly interface Meetings for the clearance. Company listed activities in the letter are sequential activities followed by pre-commissioning MST approvals and laying of cables. Company intent of listing these activities in this letter is not relevant to the context and also not clear to the contractor. However Contractor would like to record here that Asset sign off process is not part of contractor scope and these were not informed to contractor during schedule development. Company is requested to comply with clause 6 biz 2(d) of section B1 GCC “Contractor shall plan for a minimum of 2 Review/Approval cycles for each submitted document. Each review cycle shall last for ten (10) Business days from receipt, calculated from date on which company receives a contractor’s document”.

Company alleged comments are not acceptable. These requirement have been discussed with company representative on daily and weekly basis since the date of request. Contractor requested once again company to share the details as soon as possible to avoid further delays.

Company’s statement on contractor late request for communication check is not correct and unsubstantiated, hence Contractor disagrees with company’s views. Company to note that the significant delays from company side due to the lack of approval process and scope management impacted the contractor works significantly and resulted in time and cost implications. These delays and corresponding impacts are well presented by contractor through interim EOT.

Hence, Contractor claim pursuant to clause 31 biz 1(A) of section-B1 General conditions of contract remains valid and contractor reserves all its right under contract and at Law

Yours Sincerely

For Zawawi Powertech Engineering LLC,

Krishnaraj Bonagiri Project Director

question: What factors contributed to the delay in the FAT for the Power House Ventilation System in the Oman LNG Power Plant Project?
ground_truth: The delay in the FAT for the Power House Ventilation System in the Oman LNG Power Plant Project was contributed by the design finalization delay by the Company and the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as additional and late comments on the electrical system from the company, which impacted the manufacturing completion and uncertainties in logistics due to COVID-19.
contexts:
DE Zawawi Salgj «_/ Powertech Engineering L.L.C. .p.p.yH dumnigi! d8LbI) duiais

ZPTE/OLNG/LTR-134 Date: 29/07/2020

To,

M/s Oman LNG LLC,

EPC Services for Oman LNG Power Plant Project Muscat,

Sultanate of Oman.

Kind Attn: Mr. Mark McCarthy, Project Director, PMC

Contract Title: EPC Services for Oman LNG Power Plant Project Contract Number: QMP-17-876

Subject: Delay in FAT — Power House Ventilation System

Dear Sir,

With ref to the above subject, ZPTE have Placed the PO to the M/s. SAI France for the subjected package on 25" Jul 2019 and delivery of the units was scheduled on 29"" Mar 2020 which is in line to the Project approved schedule. However due to the Design finalization delay by Company and COVID-19 pandemic, the delivery is postponed and impacting the Project schedule. Despite of the delays, in line to the clause 31 biz.4 of section-B1 General conditions of contract, ZPTE have taken the mitigation action on shipment of the sub-components from the manufacturer location to avoid the delivery delay and FAT was scheduled on 22™ Jul 2020 in line with the schedule Rev-H.

Due to additional and late comments on the electrical system from company, design finalization impacted the manufacturing completion and due to the uncertainties in logistics because of the COVID-19 on delivery of the electrical equipment’s, the FAT for the unit is Currently postponed to second week of September’20 (Revised schedule will be issued shortly).

ZPTE have informed vendor to explore the options on the optimized delivery Plan to advance the delivery of the unit as part of mitigation action.

From the above, ZPTE would like to inform in line with clause 31 biz.1(d) of section b1- General conditions of the contract, that there will be delay on the delivery of the ventilation unit and it will have impact on the milestone completion.

The Vendor notification is enclosed for your reference (Attachment-1) Yours Sincerely,

For Zawawi Powertech Engineesi Rusc\

Venkat.T

Project Manager

ground_truth: S RUPESH is requesting support to expedite the dispatch of materials, highlighting the urgency due to the target of fabrication and supply being hampered. The site has given clearance to load and dispatch 15-16 vehicles per day, and the weather forecast looks promising with no uncertainties for the next 4 days. S RUPESH is urging to arrange the supply of materials on priority to meet the target of 1,132MT before the end of August 2024.

question: How have lengthy approvals and CCTV scope issues impacted the timeline and requirements for Mechanical Completion in the Oman LNG Project?
ground_truth: Lengthy approvals have caused delays in achieving Mechanical Completion requirements, as the contractor noted gross delays in obtaining approval for MCCs from the company, with some delays exceeding 90 days. Additionally, the CCTV integration scope issues have resulted in a loss of time and cost due to the company's failure to finalize the scope, which has been discussed for over a year.

question: How have design delays and approval issues affected the mechanical completion timeline for the Oman LNG Power Plant?
ground_truth: Design delays and approval issues have significantly affected the mechanical completion timeline for the Oman LNG Power Plant. The delays in obtaining approval for MCCs from the COMPANY are in excess of 90 days, and the pre-commissioning activities completion has extended from the allowed 251 days to over 400 days due to these delays.
contexts:
DE Zawawi Salgj «_/ Powertech Engineering L.L.C. .p.p.yH dumnigi! d8LbI) duiais

ZPTE/OLNG/LTR-134 Date: 29/07/2020

To,

M/s Oman LNG LLC,

EPC Services for Oman LNG Power Plant Project Muscat,

Sultanate of Oman.

Kind Attn: Mr. Mark McCarthy, Project Director, PMC

Contract Title: EPC Services for Oman LNG Power Plant Project Contract Number: QMP-17-876

Subject: Delay in FAT — Power House Ventilation System

Dear Sir,

With ref to the above subject, ZPTE have Placed the PO to the M/s. SAI France for the subjected package on 25" Jul 2019 and delivery of the units was scheduled on 29"" Mar 2020 which is in line to the Project approved schedule. However due to the Design finalization delay by Company and COVID-19 pandemic, the delivery is postponed and impacting the Project schedule. Despite of the delays, in line to the clause 31 biz.4 of section-B1 General conditions of contract, ZPTE have taken the mitigation action on shipment of the sub-components from the manufacturer location to avoid the delivery delay and FAT was scheduled on 22™ Jul 2020 in line with the schedule Rev-H.

Due to additional and late comments on the electrical system from company, design finalization impacted the manufacturing completion and due to the uncertainties in logistics because of the COVID-19 on delivery of the electrical equipment’s, the FAT for the unit is Currently postponed to second week of September’20 (Revised schedule will be issued shortly).

ZPTE have informed vendor to explore the options on the optimized delivery Plan to advance the delivery of the unit as part of mitigation action.

From the above, ZPTE would like to inform in line with clause 31 biz.1(d) of section b1- General conditions of the contract, that there will be delay on the delivery of the ventilation unit and it will have impact on the milestone completion.

The Vendor notification is enclosed for your reference (Attachment-1) Yours Sincerely,

For Zawawi Powertech Engineesi Rusc\

Venkat.T

Project Manager

question: What issues does Mr. Mark McCarthy encounter with CCTV and MCC delays in the Oman LNG project?
ground_truth: Mr. Mark McCarthy encounters issues with delays in the finalization of the CCTV integration scope and delays in obtaining approval for Mechanical Completion Certificates (MCCs) from the company, which are in excess of 90 days.

Subject: Loss of time and cost due to closure of CCTV integration scope - Notice Pursuant to clause 31 biz 1

Dear Sir,

This notice is pursuant to the clause 31 biz 1 for the loss incurred by ZPTE as a result of company failure in finalizing the CCTV integration scope for the Project.

Company to recall the chronology of the events submitted by ZPTE through above referred letter which indicates the delays from company side on the scope finalization of the CCTV integration Scope.

The delays are already addressed as a part of the Interim EOT's submission till cut off of 31st Jan 22 and further delays will be plugged in to next interim EOT . We hereby confirm the receipt of company approval vide e-mail dated 18!» Apr 22 as final scope.

ZPTE will carry out the successor actions as per durations specified in the project approved schedule for the scope. The issue of CCTV integration is being discussed since more than one year and the offer received from Vendor may not applicable. We are yet to receive the confirmation from Vendor on applicability of this offer and upon getting the confirmation, if any changes will be forwarded to Company for reimbursement.

For Zawawi Powertech Engi aineetl

question: How did COVID-19 and design delays impact the FAT timeline for the Power House Ventilation in the Oman LNG Project?
ground_truth: COVID-19 and design delays impacted the FAT timeline for the Power House Ventilation in the Oman LNG Project by postponing the delivery and impacting the project schedule. The FAT was initially scheduled for 22nd July 2020 but was postponed to the second week of September 2020 due to design finalization delays and uncertainties in logistics caused by COVID-19.

question: What milestones and land issues affect the Eastern DFC in late 2023?
ground_truth: The Eastern Dedicated Freight Corridor (DFC) in late 2023 is affected by several milestones and land issues. Milestones include the progress of track laying, ballasting, and the construction of major and minor bridge structures, with specific completion percentages provided for each structure. Land issues affecting the project include problems related to land acquisition and compensation, which are causing delays in construction activities. Additionally, there are hindrances due to the need for utility shifting, such as 132 KVA HT lines and water tanks obstructing construction progress. The total scope of the project is 54.2290 TKM, with 50.1200 TKM of land acquired, 5.1060 TKM of hindrances, and 49.1230 TKM of workable land available.
contexts:
Progress Summary from the Daily Progress Report for Eastern Freight Corridor

The Daily Progress Report for the Eastern Dedicated Freight Corridor, dated 22-11-2023, provides a detailed overview of the construction activities and status of various structures along the corridor from Khurja to Dadri. 1 Below is a summary of the progress:

Track Work and Formation

Track DN and Track UP: The progress of track laying and ballasting is ongoing across various sections. 2 Specific chainages and their completion status are detailed in the report.

Ballast DN and Ballast UP: Ballast laying activities are progressing, with specific sections marked for completion. 3

Blanket and Subgrade: The blanket and subgrade works are being carried out, with several sections completed and others in progress. 4

Embankment: Embankment works are ongoing, with half and full height embankments being constructed in various sections. 5

Clearing & Grubbing and OGL: Clearing and grubbing activities, along with Original Ground Level (OGL) recording, are being conducted to prepare the land for further construction activities. 6

Major and Minor Bridge Structures

MNB (Major Bridge) Structures: The report lists multiple MNB structures with their respective chainages and completion percentages. 7 For example:

MNB 173 (CH-1370+935): 90% completed. 8

MNB 174 (CH-1371+378): 100% completed. 9

MNB 175 (CH-1372+013): 100% completed. 10

MNB 177 (CH-1373+804): 100% completed. 11

Hindrances and Issues

Land Acquisition and Compensation: Several sections face issues related to land acquisition and compensation, which are causing delays in construction activities. Specific chainages and the nature of the hindrances are detailed in the report. 21 22

Utility Shifting: The report highlights the need for shifting utilities such as 132 KVA HT lines, water tanks, and other structures that are obstructing the construction progress. 23 24

Overall Progress

Scope and Land Acquired: The total scope of the project is 54.2290 TKM, with 50.1200 TKM of land acquired. 25

Hindrances: There are 5.1060 TKM of hindrances affecting the progress. 26

Workable Land: The workable land available is 49.1230 TKM. 27

Earthwork and Blanket: Earthwork and blanket laying activities are progressing, with specific sections marked for completion. 28

Ballast and Track: Ballast laying and track linking activities are ongoing, with several sections completed and others in progress. 29 30

This summary provides an overview of the current status and progress of the Eastern Dedicated Freight Corridor project as of 22-11-2023.
